# Description
To get the flag, you must break RSA not once, but three times!

# Provided
- [public-key.txt](209-public-key.txt)
- [encrypt.txt](209-encrypt.txt)

# Ressources
- [RSA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSA_(cryptosystem))

# Progress
I started with the public-key.txt. It contains: 3 n, e, c:<br>  
<details><summary>Values</summary>
n1 = 

n2 = 

n3 = 

e = 65537

c = 

</details>
All n above 600 digits... Not gonna factor that any time soon.

So i looked at the encrypt.txt:<br>
``` python
n1 = p * q
n2 = p * r
n3 = q * r
```
Wait a second 3 unknown variables and 3 expressions... This is solvable with plain old math:

First i rearanged the formulas, so we single out an unknown variable for each expression:

$` 
\begin{aligned}
n_1&=p\cdot q &~~~~&& n_2&=p\cdot r &~~~~&& n_3&=q\cdot r\\
p&=\frac{n_1}{q}&&&p&=\frac{n_2}{r}&&&q&=\frac{n_3}{r}
\end{aligned}
`$

Next i took the $` n_1=p\cdot q `$ and subsituted the according values:

$`
\begin{aligned}
n_1&=p\cdot q\\
&=\frac{n_2}{r}\cdot\frac{n_3}{r}\\
&=\frac{n_2n_3}{r^2}\\
n_1\cdot r^2&=n_2n_3\\
r^2&=\frac{n_2n_3}{n_1}\\
r&=\sqrt{\frac{n_2n_3}{n_1}}
\end{aligned}
`$

With r in hand i could calculate p and q by using the formulas above again.

With all the prime numbers that i need at hand i could start solving the problem using python<br>
``` python
import math
from egcd import egcd

n1= 
n2= 
n3= 
e= 65537
c= 

r=math.isqrt(n3*n2//n1)
p=n2//r
q=n3//r

phi1=(p-1)*(q-1)
phi2=(p-1)*(r-1)
phi3=(r-1)*(q-1)

d1=egcd(phi1,e)[2]%phi1
d2=egcd(phi2,e)[2]%phi2
d3=egcd(phi3,e)[2]%phi3

m=pow(c,d3,n3)
m=pow(m,d2,n2)
m=pow(m,d1,n1)

print(bytes.fromhex(hex(m)[2:]).decode('utf-8'))
```
Results in: `picoCTF{1_gu3ss_tr1pl3_rs4_1snt_tr1pl3_s3cur3!!!!!!}`
